conclusion: The problem involves determining the output power of a power source when directly connected to a resistor R, using the relationship graph of terminal voltage and current for the power source (line I) and the volt-ampere characteristic curve of the resistor R (line II).

The graph shows two intersecting lines: line I (representing the terminal voltage-current relationship of the power source) and line II (representing the voltage-ampere characteristic curve of the resistor R).

premise: The intersection of line I and line II represents the working state when the power source is directly connected to the resistor R.
conclusion: The point of intersection represents the current (I) and voltage (U) values for the closed circuit.
The intersection point of the two lines is marked by a red dot on the graph, where the voltage U = 2 V and the current I = 2 A.

premise: The voltage at the intersection point is U = 2 V, and the current is I = 2 A.
conclusion: The output power of the power source can be calculated using the formula P = U × I.

premise: Using the formula P = U × I and substituting U = 2 V and I = 2 A.
conclusion: The output power of the power source is P = 2 × 2 = 4 W.
